Issues.Title: Allow TrackByFunction be null/undefined
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

common

### Description

Imagine a complex shared table that works with different data interfaces. It accepts an array of data, configuration, and various business inputs. One of these inputs is a `trackBy` function, which is required since we have different data interfaces. However, there are cases when the default `trackBy` logic suffices and no function is needed. As a result, the `trackBy` input can either be a `TrackByFunction` or `null/undefined`. This presents a problem, as passing a `null/undefined` to `trackBy` in `ngFor` will result in an error.

Here is the reproduction
https://stackblitz.com/edit/optional-track-by

### Proposed solution

It appears that Angular already handles cases where `trackBy` is not valid and null is considered a valid value, as seen in this [code snippet](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/common/src/directives/ng_for_of.ts#L169).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22116465/227736157-4d0e7889-d932-4d17-9ce5-906fd0469c9e.png)

Under the hood, Angular assumes that `TrackByFunction` can be undefined and uses the default implementation when needed, as seen in this [code snippet](https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/main/packages/core/src/change_detection/differs/default_iterable_differ.ts#L55).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22116465/227735588-b4178cff-0abc-40f7-b511-f7e76a2855ce.png)

Therefore, the proposed solution is to extend `TrackByFunction` to accept `null/undefined` values.

### Alternatives considered

There are two potential solutions: assigning a default value for the input or handling the case of null/undefined in the template.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Allow TrackByFunction be null/undefined" (#49593)

Issues.Title: fix(zone.js): fix several behavior diffs when Promise reject unhandled
Issues.Body:
Close #47562

There are several behavior differences between ZoneAwarePromise and Native Promise.

Such as.

```
Promise.reject(new Error("test error")).finally(() => console.log("finally"));
```

1. Native Promise, will console log `finally` and throw a Promise unhandled error also process exit with code 1.
2. ZoneAwarePromise, will console log `finally` but will not output any uncaught error also process exit with code 0.

This PR fix the issue and make Promise rejection behave the same with the native one.

Issues.Title: build: enable update of `@angular/bazel`
Issues.Body:
Enables updating of `@angular/bazel`. We stopped because:

* `@angular/bazel` was updated to no longer produce CommonJS devmode
* It relied on `ts_library` patches to no longer produce CommonJS devmode.

We can make these changes to unblock the update, but it would be a significant effort as all `nodejs_binary` targets would need to be updated to execute ESM natively (as there obviously is no CJS anymore). This is what we did as an experiment in framework to run tests/code natively using `.mjs`. We are not going to do it here as we would rather want to put the effort into switching to a toolchain that supports ESM properly.. without patches.

For now we are just reversing the change in `ng_module` so that it still produces devmode CommonJS. Components repo will not use for tests etc, but it's there to allow for `nodejs_binary` CommonJS targets, and to avoid having to perform a large migration. See all the patches that are needed in framework:
https://github.com/angular/angular/tree/main/tools/esm-interop

Issues.Title: docs-bug(MatSlider): displayWith handler losing implementation context
Issues.Body:
I'm logging this issue as a continuation of the discussion in #26789.

The context of the issue is the following: the mat-slider's `displayWith` handler loses the component's context into handler implementation. We had a little conversation with @crisbeto where I provided a description of why the issue occurs, as well as a simple replication scenario, which is as follows:

`sample-slider.component.html`
```html
<mat-slider ... [displayWith]=handlerFunction">
```
and

`sample-slider.component.ts`
```ts
...
export class SampleSliderComponent {
   ...
   private _innerProperty: string = 'I want to show this text into the thumbnail formatting';

   public handlerFunction(value: number): string {
      return `${this._innerProperty} - ${value}`;
   }
}
```
_Originally posted by @3phase in https://github.com/angular/components/issues/26789#issuecomment-1470132741_

The one way to solve the issue is by explicitly setting the component's context when referring to the property, something like that:

```html
...
<mat-slider [displayWith]="handlerFunction.bind(this)></mat-slider>
```
but I think it's a hacky solution and at least has to be mentioned in the docs.
I'd either try to refactor the code so that the context isn't lost by invoking the handler from the logic of the MatSlider component (and therefore switching the implementation context), or mention it into the docs so that users don't get perplexed by the weird context shift.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(MatSlider): displayWith handler losing implementation context" (#26810)
